page.title: 03Pocahontas and Queens Pit.
page.content:
The name Indian Queens is an unusual one for a place.The explanation given by the locals is that the name comes from an overnight stop made by the Red Indian princess Pocahontas on her way to London from Falmouth early in the 17th.century.There was an inn called The Indian Queen,but it is gone now.Stagecoaches used to stop there.
Indian Queens Pit was once a tin mine in use between 1850 and 1860.It was derelict from 1860 until 1921 when it was sold for Â£60 to the Methodists of Queens and Fraddon to be used for treats and religious services.It fell into disrepair again during the Second World War and by 1970 was in an awful state.In 1976 it was restored and a Silver Jubilee service was held in 1977.Now it is used by various local organizations.
